title: 112_s3084
content: The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" is the short title of the Act. It pertains to the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" establishes 12 geographically defined Veterans Integrated Service Networks to align with the Department's mission and implement national goals for integrated healthcare systems. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" establishes 12 Veterans Integrated Service Networks to maintain regional integrated healthcare systems by implementing alliances, providing oversight of regional budgets, using national metrics for effective healthcare delivery, and ensuring high-quality clinical programs and services. The Secretary ensures high-quality clinical programs and services are provided in medical centers, outpatient clinics, and other healthcare settings within the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The reduction of duplicate functions is prioritized, and collaboration is promoted for effective patient care, safety, education, and research within the networks. The Secretary oversees operational support functions in collaboration with various entities including Veterans Benefits Administration, Department of Defense, Coast Guard, State and local agencies, medical schools, government offices, and emergency preparedness organizations within the geographical area of the network. The Secretary ensures collaboration with various entities including Veterans Benefits Administration, Department of Defense, Coast Guard, State and local agencies, medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, community and faith-based organizations, and other relevant Federal Government offices. The Veterans Integrated Service Networks develop and share innovations and best practices at local, regional, and national levels. Each network has one headquarters co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center, with a limited number of employees and contractors. The Secretary submits an annual report to Congress on employment at the headquarters of Veterans Integrated Service Networks, including the number of individuals employed, their titles, and positions within the Veterans Health Administration. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of the structure and operations of Veterans Integrated Service Networks, submitting recommendations to improve them to Congress. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of Veterans Integrated Service Networks and submits recommendations to Congress for improvement. Legislative or regulatory action may be taken to enhance the networks. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. This includes combining various networks into single entities to comply with section 7309(a) of the title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the Act's enactment. This involves combining specific networks into single entities, such as merging Veterans Integrated Service Network 9 and 10, 11 and 12, 15 and 23, 17 and 18, and 19 and 20. The consolidation of Veterans Integrated Service Networks involves merging specific networks into single entities, such as combining Veterans Integrated Service Network 20 into one network and Veterans Integrated Service Network 21 and 22 into another. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will retain one headquarters for each set of consolidated networks and eliminate any additional headquarters to meet the requirements of the law. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will find new positions for individuals whose employment is eliminated due to headquarters consolidation within the Department of Veterans Affairs. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, a plan to implement this subsection must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. Headquarters offices of Veterans Integrated Service Networks not co-located with a medical center may be relocated as per the Secretary's lease agreements. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may relocate headquarters offices not co-located with a medical center upon lease expiration or renew the lease. A report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs if a lease is renewed or a new lease is engaged in, detailing the reasons for such actions. The report must include a list of VA medical centers with underutilized buildings, current and new lease costs, and square footage details. SEC. 3. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary shall establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will evaluate finance operations, compliance activities, and outreach efforts to veterans who served in specific military operations. The Secretary will establish regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will assess programs for women veterans, homelessness among veterans, energy consumption, and other relevant operations. The Secretary may hire staff as needed, and the location of each center will be determined accordingly. The Secretary will establish regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The location of each center will be determined by the Secretary and co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center, unless a report is submitted to justify a different location. The report must include a list of underutilized buildings in the Network and the total underutilized square footage for each medical center. The Secretary will establish regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness and efficiency of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will be co-located with Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers, unless a report justifies a different location. The report must include a list of underutilized buildings and square footage for each medical center. Additionally, the initial staffing for these centers will involve transferring employees from headquarters to cover similar functions. The Act establishes regional support centers for Veterans Integrated Service Networks within the Veterans Health Administration. It does not mandate changes in the location or type of care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
